nodes.title: object
nodes.content:
# object


An object is an abstract concept arising in mathematics. 
Typically, a mathematical object can be a value that can be assigned to a symbol.

nodes.title: information
nodes.content:
# information


An abstract concept that refers to something which has the power to inform. 
At the most fundamental level, it pertains to the interpretation (perhaps formally) of that which may be 
sensed, or their abstractions. Any natural process that is not completely random and any observable 
pattern in any medium can be said to convey some amount of information.

nodes.title: sequence
nodes.content:
# sequence


A collection of [objects](mathematics/object) in which repetitions are allowed and order 
matters.

nodes.title: finite_sequence
nodes.content:
# finite_sequence


A [sequence](mathematics/sequence) that has a finite number of 
[objects](mathematics/object). Informally, a finite sequence is a sequence which one could in 
principle count and finish counting. For example, (2,4,6,8,10) is a finite sequence with five elements.

nodes.title: instruction
nodes.content:
# instruction


A detailed [information](mathematics/information) about how something should be done or operated.

nodes.title: index
nodes.content:
# index


[index](mathematics/index) is an [integer](mathematics/integer) value that identifies the position of an element 
within a [sequence](mathematics/sequence). Indices are used to access, modify, or reference specific 
elements, and can be zero-based (starting at 0) or one-based (starting at 1) depending on the context.

nodes.title: loop
nodes.content:
# loop


[loop](mathematics/loop) is a control structure that repeats a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of [instructions](mathematics/instruction) 
multiple times until a specified condition is met or for a predetermined number of iterations. Loops enable efficient 
execution of repetitive tasks and are fundamental to iterating over data structures.

nodes.title: last in first out
nodes.content:
# last in first out


[last in first out](mathematics/last_in_first_out) is an ordering principle where the most recently added element in a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) 
is the first one to be removed. In this scheme, the last element that enters is the first one to exit, 
similar to a stack of plates where you can only access the top plate.

nodes.title: operation
nodes.content:
# operation


A mathematical action performed on one or more [objects](mathematics/object) to produce a result.

nodes.title: relation
nodes.content:
# relation


A relation (also called relationship) describes a connection or association between elements of a 
[set(s)](mathematics/set).

nodes.title: set
nodes.content:
# set


Set is a group of different things. These things are called elements or members of the set and are typically 
mathematical [objects](mathematics/object) of any kind.

nodes.title: finite_set
nodes.content:
# finite_set


Finite set is a [set](mathematics/set) that has a finite number of elements. 
Informally, a finite set is a set which one could in principle count and finish counting. 
For example, {2,4,6,8,10}  is a finite set with five elements.

nodes.title: function
nodes.content:
# function


Function it is a kind of [relation](mathematics/relation) which from a set X to a set Y 
assigns to each element (or [object](mathematics/object)) of X exactly one element of Y.

nodes.title: hash_function
nodes.content:
# hash_function


A function that for an input [object](mathematics/object) assigns a fixed-size text. 
The text is typically a 'digest' that is unique to each unique input.

nodes.title: pure function
nodes.content:
# pure function


A [pure function](mathematics/pure_function) is a [function](mathematics/function) that always returns the same result 
for the same [input](mathematics/input_data). Pure functions are deterministic and depend only 
on their input values to produce their output values.

nodes.title: polynomial
nodes.content:
# polynomial


A [polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) is a mathematical expression consisting of variables and coefficients, 
involving only the [operations](mathematics/operation) of addition, subtraction, multiplication, 
and non-negative [integer](mathematics/integer) exponentiation of variables. A 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) is a type of [function](mathematics/function) that can be written in the form 
a_n*x^n + a_(n-1)*x^(n-1) + ... + a_1*x + a_0, where the coefficients a_i are constants and n is a 
non-negative [integer](mathematics/integer) called the degree of the polynomial.

nodes.title: multiset
nodes.content:
# multiset


A multiset is a [set](mathematics/set) that allows for multiple occurrences of the same element. 
Unlike a traditional set, which only allows unique elements, a multi-set can contain duplicates. This means that 
the same element can appear more than once.

nodes.title: label
nodes.content:
# label


A label is a name, number, or symbol attached to an [object](mathematics/object) to give it 
meaning or identify it.

nodes.title: asymptotic_behavior
nodes.content:
# asymptotic_behavior


The behavior of a [function](mathematics/function) as its input approaches infinity or some other limit value. 
Asymptotic behavior describes how a function grows or behaves in the limit, focusing on the dominant terms and 
ignoring lower-order terms and constant factors.

nodes.title: bound
nodes.content:
# bound


A limit on the values that a [function](mathematics/function) or expression can take. A bound constrains or 
restricts the range or growth of values, providing a reference point for comparison.

nodes.title: upper_bound
nodes.content:
# upper_bound


A [bound](mathematics/bound) that establishes the maximum value or growth rate that a 
[function](mathematics/function) or expression can achieve. An upper bound provides a ceiling or constraint 
on how large values can become.

nodes.title: big_o_notation
nodes.content:
# big_o_notation


A mathematical notation used to describe the [asymptotic_behavior](mathematics/asymptotic_behavior) of a 
[function](mathematics/function), particularly the [upper_bound](mathematics/upper_bound) of 
[time_complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) or [space_complexity](mathematics/space_complexity) as the input size grows. 
Big O notation characterizes the worst-case growth rate, allowing comparison of algorithm efficiency 
independent of implementation details.

nodes.title: Turing machine
nodes.content:
# Turing machine


A [Turing machine](mathematics/turing_machine) is a mathematical model of computation that defines an abstract machine. 
It consists of an infinite tape divided into cells, a head that can read and write symbols on the tape, 
a state register that stores the machine's current state, and a finite table of 
[instructions](mathematics/instruction) that determines the machine's behavior. The Turing machine 
processes input by following a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of state transitions based on the current state 
and the symbol being read.

nodes.title: deterministic Turing machine
nodes.content:
# deterministic Turing machine


A [deterministic Turing machine](mathematics/deterministic_turing_machine) is a [Turing machine](mathematics/turing_machine) where each 
[instruction](mathematics/instruction) uniquely determines the next state and action. Given the current 
state and the symbol being read, there is exactly one possible transition, making the machine's behavior 
completely predictable and reproducible.

nodes.title: nondeterministic Turing machine
nodes.content:
# nondeterministic Turing machine


A [nondeterministic Turing machine](mathematics/nondeterministic_turing_machine) is a [Turing machine](mathematics/turing_machine) where each 
[instruction](mathematics/instruction) can have multiple possible next states and actions. Given the current 
state and the symbol being read, the machine can "choose" among several possible transitions, effectively 
exploring multiple computational paths simultaneously. This is a theoretical model that allows the machine 
to make the "right" choice at each step, making it more powerful than its deterministic counterpart for 
analyzing computational complexity.

nodes.title: problem
nodes.content:
# problem


A question or a challenge defined in a formal way.

nodes.title: problem space
nodes.content:
# problem space


[problem space](mathematics/problem_space) is the [set](mathematics/set) of all possible candidates for 
[solutions](mathematics/solution) to a [problem](mathematics/problem). It represents the entire 
domain that must be searched through to find a valid or [optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution). 
The size of the problem space directly impacts computational efficiency, as larger problem spaces typically require 
more computational resources to explore.

nodes.title: complement problem
nodes.content:
# complement problem


The [complement problem](mathematics/complement_problem) of a decision [problem](mathematics/problem) is obtained by swapping 
the "yes" and "no" answers. If the original problem accepts a [solution](mathematics/solution) as "yes", 
the complement problem answers "no" for the same solution, and vice versa. For example, if a problem 
asks "Is this graph connected?", its complement asks "Is this graph disconnected?". The complement 
inverts the acceptance [criteria](mathematics/criterion) while keeping the same 
[input](mathematics/input_data) structure.

nodes.title: input data
nodes.content:
# input data


The [input data](mathematics/input_data) is the [information](mathematics/information) provided to a 
[function](mathematics/function) to be processed. 
It represents the initial state or values that the function operates on to produce an output.

nodes.title: criterion
nodes.content:
# criterion


A standard or principle by which something is judged or decided.

nodes.title: optimal_solution
nodes.content:
# optimal_solution


A [solution](mathematics/solution) that is the best among all possible solutions, often in terms 
of a specific [criterion](mathematics/criterion).

nodes.title: optimal_substructure
nodes.content:
# optimal_substructure


A [problem](mathematics/problem) is said to have optimal substructure if an 
[optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) can be constructed from optimal solutions of its 
[subproblems](mathematics/subproblem).

nodes.title: solution
nodes.content:
# solution


A method or process for solving a [problem](mathematics/problem), often involving a 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) of steps or [operations](mathematics/operation).

nodes.title: subproblem
nodes.content:
# subproblem


A smaller, more manageable [problem](mathematics/problem) derived from a larger problem, often 
used in the context of problem-solving and algorithm design.

nodes.title: overlapping_subproblems
nodes.content:
# overlapping_subproblems


A [problem](mathematics/problem) is said to have overlapping 
[subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) if the problem can be broken down into smaller, 
simpler subproblems that are reused several times.

nodes.title: algorithm
nodes.content:
# algorithm


A [finite sequence](mathematics/finite_sequence) of mathematically rigorous 
[instructions](mathematics/instruction), typically used to solve a 
[problem](mathematics/problem).

nodes.title: heuristic
nodes.content:
# heuristic


A [heuristic](mathematics/heuristic) is a [function](mathematics/function) or strategy used in an 
[algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) to guide decision-making when finding a [solution](mathematics/solution) to a 
[problem](mathematics/problem). It provides an estimate that helps the algorithm make more informed choices 
by evaluating different options, allowing algorithms to explore more promising paths first and improve efficiency.

nodes.title: complexity
nodes.content:
# complexity


A measure of the resources required by an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) to solve a 
[problem](mathematics/problem), typically expressed as a [function](mathematics/function) of the input size. 
Complexity quantifies how the resource requirements grow as the input size increases, helping to evaluate 
and compare algorithm efficiency.

nodes.title: amortized time
nodes.content:
# amortized time


[amortized time](mathematics/amortized_time) is a method of analyzing the [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) 
of a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of [operations](mathematics/operation) by calculating the average 
cost per [operation](mathematics/operation) over the entire sequence, rather than analyzing individual operations 
in isolation. This approach is particularly useful for [algorithms](mathematics/algorithm) 
where some operations are expensive but occur infrequently, while most operations are cheap. Amortized analysis 
guarantees that the average cost per operation over any sequence remains [bounded](mathematics/bound), 
even though individual operations may occasionally be costly.

nodes.title: time_complexity
nodes.content:
# time_complexity


A measure of [complexity](mathematics/complexity) that quantifies the amount of time an 
[algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) takes to complete as a [function](mathematics/function) of the input size. 
Time complexity describes how the number of operations or execution time grows with increasing input size.

nodes.title: space_complexity
nodes.content:
# space_complexity


A measure of [complexity](mathematics/complexity) that quantifies the amount of memory or storage space an 
[algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) requires as a [function](mathematics/function) of the input size. 
Space complexity describes how the memory requirements grow with increasing input size.

nodes.title: logarithmic complexity
nodes.content:
# logarithmic complexity


[logarithmic complexity](mathematics/logarithmic_complexity) is a [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) classification where 
an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) performs a number of [operations](mathematics/operation) that grows 
logarithmically with the size of the [input](mathematics/input_data). Expressed in 
[Big O notation](mathematics/big_o_notation) as O(log n), logarithmic complexity means that each 
[operation](mathematics/operation) reduces the [problem space](mathematics/problem_space) by a constant 
factor (typically by half). This is highly efficient and commonly seen in algorithms that repeatedly divide the problem 
space. Logarithmic complexity is significantly faster than linear complexity, especially for large inputs, as doubling 
the [input](mathematics/input_data) size only adds one additional [operation](mathematics/operation).

nodes.title: real-world performance
nodes.content:
# real-world performance


The [real-world performance](mathematics/real_world_performance) of an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) refers to its actual execution 
efficiency in practical applications, as opposed to theoretical 
[complexity](mathematics/complexity) analysis. While [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) 
and [space complexity](mathematics/space_complexity) provide 
[asymptotic](mathematics/asymptotic_behavior) [bounds](mathematics/bound) that describe 
how an algorithm scales, real-world performance considers the actual runtime behavior with typical 
[input data](mathematics/input_data) and implementation-specific factors. An algorithm with better 
theoretical complexity may perform worse in practice, and vice versa.

nodes.title: best conceivable runtime
nodes.content:
# best conceivable runtime


[best conceivable runtime](mathematics/best_conceivable_runtime) (BCR) is the theoretical best [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) 
that any [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) could possibly achieve for solving a particular [problem](mathematics/problem). 
It represents a lower [bound](mathematics/bound) on the runtime based on the fundamental [constraints](mathematics/constraint) of the problem, 
such as the amount of [input](mathematics/input_data) that must be examined or the output that must be produced. The BCR helps identify whether 
an algorithm can be further optimized or if it has already achieved the best possible performance.

nodes.title: brute_force
nodes.content:
# brute_force


A type of [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that solves a [problem](mathematics/problem) by systematically checking 
all possible candidates for a [solution](mathematics/solution) until the correct one is found. Brute force algorithms 
are straightforward and guarantee finding the [optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) if one exists, 
but they can be computationally expensive for large problem spaces as they do not employ any [optimization](mathematics/optimization) techniques.

nodes.title: BUD
nodes.content:
# BUD


[BUD](mathematics/bud) is an [optimization](mathematics/optimization) framework for improving [algorithms](mathematics/algorithm) 
by identifying and addressing three types of inefficiencies: Bottlenecks (the slowest parts that limit overall performance), 
Unnecessary work (operations that can be eliminated without affecting the result), and Duplicated work (redundant computations 
that can be avoided by reusing previously computed results). By systematically examining these three areas, BUD helps 
identify opportunities for performance improvement.

nodes.title: dynamic_programming
nodes.content:
# dynamic_programming


A type of [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that solves a [problem](mathematics/problem) by breaking it down into 
simpler [subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) and storing their [solutions](mathematics/solution) 
to avoid redundant computations. Dynamic programming is particularly effective for problems that exhibit 
[overlapping_subproblems](mathematics/overlapping_subproblems) and [optimal_substructure](mathematics/optimal_substructure), enabling the 
construction of an [optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) by reusing previously computed results.

nodes.title: memoization
nodes.content:
# memoization


An [optimization](mathematics/optimization) technique that stores the results of expensive [function](mathematics/function) calls 
and returns the stored result when the same inputs occur again. [memoization](mathematics/memoization) is particularly effective for 
[recursive](mathematics/recursion) [functions](mathematics/function) with [overlapping_subproblems](mathematics/overlapping_subproblems), 
where the same [subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) are computed multiple times. By storing previously 
computed [solutions](mathematics/solution), memoization significantly reduces redundant computations and 
improves performance.

nodes.title: Co-NP class
nodes.content:
# Co-NP class


[Co-NP class](mathematics/co_np_class) is a [complexity](mathematics/complexity) class in computational 
complexity theory that contains all decision [problems](mathematics/problem) whose 
[complement](mathematics/complement_problem) is in [NP](mathematics/np_class). A 
problem is in Co-NP if the "no" instances can be verified by a 
[deterministic Turing machine](mathematics/deterministic_turing_machine) in 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity). 
Equivalently, the [complement](mathematics/complement_problem) of the problem can be solved by a 
[nondeterministic Turing machine](mathematics/nondeterministic_turing_machine) in time 
[O(n^k)](mathematics/big_o_notation) for some constant k, where n is the size of the 
[input data](mathematics/input_data). Co-NP stands for "Complement of NP."

nodes.title: NP class
nodes.content:
# NP class


[NP class](mathematics/np_class) is a [complexity](mathematics/complexity) class in computational 
complexity theory that contains all decision [problems](mathematics/problem) that can be solved 
by a [nondeterministic Turing machine](mathematics/nondeterministic_turing_machine) in 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity). 
Equivalently, a problem is in NP if, given a proposed [solution](mathematics/solution), there exists a 
[deterministic Turing machine](mathematics/deterministic_turing_machine) that can verify the 
solution's correctness in time [O(n^k)](mathematics/big_o_notation) for some constant k, where 
n is the size of the [input data](mathematics/input_data). NP stands for "Nondeterministic Polynomial time."

nodes.title: NP-Complete class
nodes.content:
# NP-Complete class


[NP-Complete class](mathematics/np_complete_class) is a class of [problems](mathematics/problem) that are both in 
[NP](mathematics/np_class) and [NP-Hard](mathematics/np_hard_class). A problem is 
NP-Complete if: (1) given a proposed [solution](mathematics/solution), it can be verified by a 
[deterministic Turing machine](mathematics/deterministic_turing_machine) in 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) [time](mathematics/time_complexity), and (2) every 
problem in NP can be [reduced](mathematics/reduction) to it in polynomial time. NP-Complete 
problems are the "hardest" problems in NP - if any NP-Complete problem can be solved efficiently, then all 
problems in NP can be solved efficiently. The size of the [input data](mathematics/input_data) affects the 
computational difficulty.

nodes.title: NP-Hard class
nodes.content:
# NP-Hard class


[NP-Hard class](mathematics/np_hard_class) is a class of [problems](mathematics/problem) in computational 
complexity theory that are at least as hard as the hardest problems in [NP](mathematics/np_class). 
A problem is NP-Hard if every problem in NP can be [reduced](mathematics/reduction) to it in 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) [time](mathematics/time_complexity). This means that 
if we had an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) to solve an NP-Hard problem efficiently, we could use it to 
solve all NP problems efficiently. NP-Hard problems are not necessarily in NP themselves - they may be even 
harder, with no way to verify solutions quickly. The [reduction](mathematics/reduction) is used as a 
theoretical tool to prove hardness, not to solve problems. The size of the [input data](mathematics/input_data) 
determines the complexity of solving NP-Hard problems.

nodes.title: optimization
nodes.content:
# optimization


The process of improving an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) or [solution](mathematics/solution) to make it more 
efficient by reducing resource consumption. [optimization](mathematics/optimization) 
involves finding the best approach to solve a [problem](mathematics/problem) within given [constraints](mathematics/constraint), often by 
minimizing costs or maximizing benefits.

nodes.title: P class
nodes.content:
# P class


[P class](mathematics/p_class) is a [complexity](mathematics/complexity) class in computational 
complexity theory that contains all decision [problems](mathematics/problem) that can be solved 
by a [deterministic Turing machine](mathematics/deterministic_turing_machine) in 
[polynomial](mathematics/polynomial) [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity). 
A problem is in P if there exists an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that can solve any instance of the 
problem in time [O(n^k)](mathematics/big_o_notation) for some constant k, where n is the size 
of the [input data](mathematics/input_data). Problems in P are considered efficiently solvable or tractable.

nodes.title: A-star algorithm
nodes.content:
# A-star algorithm


The [A-star algorithm](mathematics/a_star_algorithm) is a [greedy](mathematics/greedy_algorithm) 
[algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that finds the shortest [path](mathematics/path) between two 
[nodes](mathematics/node) in a weighted [graph](mathematics/graph). It extends 
[Dijkstra's algorithm](mathematics/dijkstras_algorithm) by using a [heuristic function](mathematics/heuristic) 
to estimate the [distance](mathematics/graph_distance) from the current node to the goal node, 
allowing it to prioritize more promising paths and find the shortest path more efficiently. 
The algorithm maintains two costs: the actual cost from the start node (g-score) and the estimated 
total cost through the current node to the goal (f-score = g-score + heuristic). 
It requires the heuristic to be admissible (never overestimating the actual cost) to guarantee 
finding the optimal path.

nodes.title: dijkstras_algorithm
nodes.content:
# dijkstras_algorithm


A [greedy](mathematics/greedy_algorithm) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that finds the shortest 
[paths](mathematics/path) from a single source [node](mathematics/node) to all other 
nodes in a weighted [graph](mathematics/graph) with non-negative 
[edge](mathematics/edge) weights. The algorithm maintains a set of nodes for which the shortest 
[distance](mathematics/graph_distance) from the source is known, and iteratively selects the node with 
the minimum distance to expand the set until all nodes are processed.

nodes.title: bellman_ford_algorithm
nodes.content:
# bellman_ford_algorithm


A [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that computes shortest [paths](mathematics/path) from a single source 
[node](mathematics/node) to all other nodes in a weighted [graph](mathematics/graph). The algorithm iteratively 
relaxes all [edges](mathematics/edge) by updating [distances](mathematics/graph_distance) if a 
shorter path is found, repeating this process for each node in the graph. Unlike 
[Dijkstra's algorithm](mathematics/dijkstras_algorithm), Bellman-Ford can handle negative edge weights and 
can detect negative-weight [cycles](mathematics/cycle), making it more versatile for certain applications.

nodes.title: Floyd-Warshall algorithm
nodes.content:
# Floyd-Warshall algorithm


The [Floyd-Warshall algorithm](mathematics/floyd_warshall_algorithm) is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that finds the shortest 
[paths](mathematics/path) between all pairs of [nodes](mathematics/node) in a weighted 
[graph](mathematics/graph). The algorithm uses [dynamic programming](mathematics/dynamic_programming) 
by iteratively considering each node as an intermediate node and updating the 
[distances](mathematics/graph_distance) between all pairs of nodes if a shorter path through 
the intermediate node is found. It can handle negative [edge](mathematics/edge) weights but 
cannot handle negative-weight [cycles](mathematics/cycle). The algorithm has a [time complexity](mathematics/time_complexity) 
of O(V) where V is the number of nodes, making it efficient for dense graphs or when all-pairs shortest paths are needed.

nodes.title: cycle detection
nodes.content:
# cycle detection


[cycle detection](mathematics/cycle_detection) is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) for determining whether a 
[graph](mathematics/graph) contains a [cycle](mathematics/cycle). The algorithm typically uses 
[depth-first search](mathematics/depth_first_search) to traverse the graph while tracking 
visited [nodes](mathematics/node) and the current [path](mathematics/path). If a node is encountered 
that is already in the current path, a cycle has been detected. Different approaches are used for 
[directed](mathematics/directed_graph) versus undirected graphs.

nodes.title: graph
nodes.content:
# graph


Graphs are used to model pairwise [relations](mathematics/relation) between objects. 
A graph is made up of [nodes](mathematics/node) and [edges](mathematics/edge). 
Graphs can be directed or undirected, weighted or unweighted, and can represent various types of 
relationships in different fields.

nodes.title: node
nodes.content:
# node


A node (also called vertex) is an abstract entity that can represent an [object](mathematics/object) 
or position in a structure. It does not imply any connections or context on its own.

nodes.title: edge
nodes.content:
# edge


An edge is a directed or undirected connection between two [nodes](mathematics/node). 
It defines a [relationship](mathematics/relation) or link between them.

nodes.title: adjacency_list
nodes.content:
# adjacency_list


An adjacency list is a way of representing a [graph](mathematics/graph) as a collection of lists. 
Each list corresponds to a [node](mathematics/node) in the graph and contains a list of its 
adjacent nodes.

nodes.title: bipartite_graph
nodes.content:
# bipartite_graph


A [graph](mathematics/graph) whose [nodes](mathematics/node) can be divided into 
two disjoint [sets](mathematics/set) such that every [edge](mathematics/edge) 
connects a node in one set to a node in the other set. In other words, there are no edges connecting nodes 
within the same set.

nodes.title: cycle
nodes.content:
# cycle


A cycle in a [graph](mathematics/graph) is a non-empty [path](mathematics/path) 
in which only the first and last [nodes](mathematics/node) are equal.

nodes.title: directed_acyclic_graph
nodes.content:
# directed_acyclic_graph


A directed acyclic graph is a [directed graph](mathematics/directed_graph) with no 
[cycles](mathematics/cycle).

nodes.title: directed_graph
nodes.content:
# directed_graph


A directed graph is a [graph](mathematics/graph) in which the 
[edges](mathematics/edge) have a direction. Each edge connects an ordered pair of 
[nodes](mathematics/node), meaning that the connection goes from one node to another in a 
specific direction.

nodes.title: graph_distance
nodes.content:
# graph_distance


A measure of the shortest [path](mathematics/path) between two 
[nodes](mathematics/node) in a [graph](mathematics/graph).

nodes.title: path
nodes.content:
# path


A path in a [graph](mathematics/graph) is a [finite](mathematics/finite_set) or 
infinite sequence of [edges](mathematics/edge) which joins a sequence of 
[nodes](mathematics/node) which, by most definitions, are all distinct (and since the nodes are 
distinct, so are the edges).

nodes.title: weighted graph
nodes.content:
# weighted graph


A [weighted graph](mathematics/weighted_graph) is a [graph](mathematics/graph) in which each [edge](mathematics/edge) 
has an associated numerical value called a weight. The weight typically represents a cost, distance, 
capacity, or other metric relevant to the problem being modeled. Weighted graphs are used in many 
algorithms where the [relationship](mathematics/relation) between nodes has varying significance or cost.

nodes.title: avl_tree
nodes.content:
# avl_tree


A type of [self-balancing](mathematics/b_tree) 
[binary search tree](mathematics/binary_search_tree) where the difference in heights between the 
left and right [subtrees](mathematics/subtree) of any [node](mathematics/node) is at 
most one. This property ensures that the tree remains approximately balanced, allowing for efficient search, 
insertion, and deletion operations. The AVL tree is named after its inventors, Georgy Adelson-Velsky and 
Evgenii Landis.

nodes.title: b_tree
nodes.content:
# b_tree


A self-balancing [tree](mathematics/tree) data structure in which each 
[node](mathematics/node) has a value, and for each node, the values of all nodes in its left 
[subtree](mathematics/subtree) are less than its own value, and the values of all nodes in its 
right subtree are greater than its own value. This property allows for efficient searching, insertion, and 
deletion operations.

nodes.title: balanced_binary_tree
nodes.content:
# balanced_binary_tree


A type of [binary tree](mathematics/binary_tree) in which the depth of the two subtrees of every 
[node](mathematics/node) never differs by more than one. This means that for any given node in the 
tree, the height of its left and right subtrees can differ by at most one.

nodes.title: binary_search_tree
nodes.content:
# binary_search_tree


A special case of a [b_tree](mathematics/b_tree) in that a [node](mathematics/node) 
can only have maximum two children.

nodes.title: binary_tree
nodes.content:
# binary_tree


A [tree](mathematics/tree) in which each node has at most two children, referred to as the left 
child and the right child. A binary tree is a special case of a [k-ary tree](mathematics/k_ary_tree) 
where k = 2.

nodes.title: complete_binary_tree
nodes.content:
# complete_binary_tree


A [binary tree](mathematics/binary_tree) in which every level, except possibly the last, is 
completely filled, and all [nodes](mathematics/node) are as far left as possible. In a complete 
binary tree, all nodes at the last level are filled from left to right. It can have between 1 and 2h nodes at 
the last level h.

nodes.title: interval_tree
nodes.content:
# interval_tree


A type of [binary search tree](mathematics/binary_search_tree) that stores intervals as its keys. 
Each [node](mathematics/node) in the interval tree represents an interval, and the tree is 
structured in such a way that it allows for efficient searching of all intervals that overlap with a given 
interval or point. The intervals are typically represented by their start and end points, and the 
[tree](mathematics/tree) is [balanced](mathematics/balanced_binary_tree) to ensure 
efficient search operations.

nodes.title: k_ary_tree
nodes.content:
# k_ary_tree


A [tree](mathematics/tree) in which each [node](mathematics/node) has at most k 
children. The maximum number of nodes at level h of a k-ary tree is k^h, and the maximum number of nodes in a 
k-ary tree of height h is (k^(h+1) - 1) / (k - 1).

nodes.title: leaf
nodes.content:
# leaf


A [node](mathematics/node) in a tree that does not have any children (descendants).

nodes.title: minimum_spanning_tree
nodes.content:
# minimum_spanning_tree


A [tree](mathematics/tree) that connects all the [nodes](mathematics/node) in a 
[graph](mathematics/graph) with the minimum possible total [edge](mathematics/edge) 
weight. In other words, it is a subset of the edges of the graph that forms a tree and includes every node, such 
that the sum of the weights of the edges is minimized.

nodes.title: red_black_tree
nodes.content:
# red_black_tree


A type of [self-balancing](mathematics/b_tree) 
[binary search tree](mathematics/binary_search_tree). The red-black tree is named after the colors 
used to represent the [nodes](mathematics/node). The tree maintains certain properties to ensure 
that it remains approximately balanced, allowing for efficient search, insertion, and deletion operations. 
The properties include: 1. Each node is either red or black. 2. The root node is always black. 3. All 
[leaves](mathematics/leaf) are black. 4. If a red node has children, then both children are black. 
5. Every path from a node to its descendant leaves has the same number of black nodes. These properties ensure 
that the tree remains approximately balanced, allowing for efficient search, insertion, and deletion operations.

nodes.title: subtree
nodes.content:
# subtree


A [tree](mathematics/tree) formed from a [node](mathematics/node) and all its 
descendants in a tree.

nodes.title: tree
nodes.content:
# tree


A tree is a [directed acyclic graph](mathematics/directed_acyclic_graph) with the restriction that 
a child can only have one parent. Each tree has a root [node](mathematics/node), which is the 
topmost node in the hierarchy, and each node can have zero or more child nodes. Each node has only one parent 
node, except for the root node, which has no parent.

nodes.title: unbalanced_binary_tree
nodes.content:
# unbalanced_binary_tree


A [binary tree](mathematics/binary_tree) that does not satisfy the 
[balanced binary tree](mathematics/balanced_binary_tree) property. In an unbalanced binary tree, 
the depth of the two [subtrees](mathematics/subtree) of at least one 
[node](mathematics/node) differs by more than one.

nodes.title: heap_tree
nodes.content:
# heap_tree


A type of [tree](mathematics/tree) data structure that satisfies the heap property: the value of 
each [node](mathematics/node) is greater than or equal to (or less than or equal to) the values of 
its children. This property allows for efficient retrieval of the minimum (or maximum) element in the tree.

nodes.title: reduction
nodes.content:
# reduction


Reduction refers to the rewriting of an expression into a simpler form. It is process of transforming a 
[problem](mathematics/problem) into a simpler or smaller instance of the same or a 
[related](mathematics/relation) problem, often to make it easier to solve.

nodes.title: base_case
nodes.content:
# base_case


The simplest instance of the [problem](mathematics/problem), which can be 
[solved](mathematics/solution) directly without further [reduction](mathematics/reduction).

nodes.title: recursion
nodes.content:
# recursion


A method of solving a [problem](mathematics/problem) where the [solution](mathematics/solution) depends on solutions 
to smaller instances of the same problem. Recursion involves a [function](mathematics/function) calling itself with 
simpler inputs until reaching a [base_case](mathematics/base_case).

nodes.title: greedy_algorithm
nodes.content:
# greedy_algorithm


A type of [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that builds up a [solution](mathematics/solution) piece by piece, always 
choosing the next piece that offers the most immediate benefit. Greedy algorithms do not always produce the 
[optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution), but they are often faster and simpler than other 
approaches.

nodes.title: divide_and_conquer
nodes.content:
# divide_and_conquer


A type of [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that solves a [problem](mathematics/problem) by 
[recursively](mathematics/recursion) breaking it down into smaller 
[subproblems](mathematics/subproblem), solving each subproblem independently, and then combining their 
[solutions](mathematics/solution) to form a solution to the original problem. Divide and conquer 
algorithms often lead to efficient and elegant solutions. They may or may not always produce the 
[optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution).

nodes.title: sorting
nodes.content:
# sorting


Sorting is an [algorithmic](mathematics/algorithm) process that arranges the elements of a 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) or [set](mathematics/set) in a certain order, 
typically according to a specified [relation](mathematics/relation) (such as ascending or 
descending).

nodes.title: quick_sort
nodes.content:
# quick_sort


QuickSort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that uses a 
[divide_and_conquer](mathematics/divide_and_conquer) approach to sort elements. It selects a 'pivot' element, partitions the 
other elements into two sub-[sequences](mathematics/sequence) according to whether they are less than or 
greater than the pivot, and then [recursively](mathematics/recursion) sorts the sub-sequences.

nodes.title: selection_sort
nodes.content:
# selection_sort


SelectionSort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that sorts an 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) by repeatedly finding the minimum (or maximum) element from the unsorted 
part and moving it to the beginning (or end). This process is repeated until the entire sequence is sorted.

nodes.title: probability
nodes.content:
# probability


Probability is a measure that quantifies the likelihood of elements in a [set](mathematics/set) or events, 
typically expressed as a number between 0 and 1. Probabilities indicate how likely different 
[objects](mathematics/object) or outcomes are to occur.

nodes.title: distribution
nodes.content:
# distribution


A distribution describes how values (or outcomes) are spread over a domain. Typically it associates elements of a 
[set](mathematics/set) or values to their frequencies or 
[probabilities](mathematics/probability), describing how likely or how common different 
[objects](mathematics/object) are.

nodes.title: uniform_distribution
nodes.content:
# uniform_distribution


A uniform distribution is a [distribution](mathematics/distribution) in which all elements of a 
[set](mathematics/set) are assigned equal weight or probability, so each outcome is equally likely.

nodes.title: merge
nodes.content:
# merge


Merge is an [operation](mathematics/operation) that combines two [sequences](mathematics/sequence) into a 
single sequence by interleaving their elements while preserving the order of each input sequence.

nodes.title: merge_sort
nodes.content:
# merge_sort


MergeSort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that uses a 
[divide_and_conquer](mathematics/divide_and_conquer) approach: it divides the input 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) into two halves, [recursively](mathematics/recursion) sorts each 
half, and then merges the two sorted halves into a single sorted [sequence](mathematics/sequence).

nodes.title: bucket_sort
nodes.content:
# bucket_sort


BucketSort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that distributes the elements of a 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) into a number of buckets, sorts each bucket individually (often using 
another [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm)), and then concatenates the sorted buckets to produce the final sorted 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence). Bucket sort can be very efficient when input is uniformly distributed; 
in some cases it can achieve linear time and approach the [optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) 
for specific distributions.

nodes.title: number
nodes.content:
# number


A number is a mathematical [object](mathematics/object) used to count, measure, and label.

nodes.title: integer
nodes.content:
# integer


An integer is the [number](mathematics/number) zero (0), a positive natural number (1, 2, 3, ...), or the 
negation of a positive natural number (-1, -2, -3, ...). The negations or additive inverses of the positive 
natural numbers are referred to as negative integers.

nodes.title: radix
nodes.content:
# radix


A radix is the base of a positional number system. It is the number of unique digits, including the digit zero, 
used to represent numbers. For example, base-10 (decimal) has radix 10.

nodes.title: radix_sort
nodes.content:
# radix_sort


[Radix](mathematics/radix) Sort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that sorts 
a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of [integers](mathematics/integer) 
(or other [objects](mathematics/object) that can be represented by integers) by processing individual 
digits or positions of the keys, grouping elements by each digit from least significant to most (LSD) 
or most to least significant (MSD). It is a non-comparative sorting technique: instead of comparing 
elements directly, it distributes them into buckets according to the value of the current digit and then 
collects them in order. When the number of digits (or key range per digit) is bounded, radix sort can 
run in linear time with respect to the number of elements and thus approach the 
[optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) 
for those inputs."

nodes.title: bubble_sort
nodes.content:
# bubble_sort


Bubble Sort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that repeatedly steps through a 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence), compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. 
This process is repeated until the entire [sequence](mathematics/sequence) is sorted. Bubble sort is 
simple but generally inefficient for large inputs, as it repeatedly passes over the sequence.

nodes.title: heap_sort
nodes.content:
# heap_sort


Heap Sort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that builds a 
[heap tree](mathematics/heap_tree) from the elements of a [sequence](mathematics/sequence), 
and then repeatedly extracts the root (the maximum or minimum) and restores the heap until the entire 
[sequence](mathematics/sequence) is sorted.

nodes.title: topological_sort
nodes.content:
# topological_sort


Topological Sort is a [sorting](mathematics/sorting) [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) applied to a 
[directed acyclic graph](mathematics/directed_acyclic_graph). It produces a linear ordering 
of the graph's vertices such that for every directed edge (u, v), u comes before v in the ordering.

nodes.title: binary_search
nodes.content:
# binary_search


Binary Search is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that finds the position of a target value 
within a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half. 
Binary search requires the [sequence](mathematics/sequence) to be [sorted](mathematics/sorting). 
At each step it compares the target with the middle element of the interval and then continues 
the search on the left or right half, effectively using a [divide_and_conquer](mathematics/divide_and_conquer) approach.

nodes.title: bidirectional search
nodes.content:
# bidirectional search


The [bidirectional search](mathematics/bidirectional_search) is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) for finding a [path](mathematics/path) 
between two [nodes](mathematics/node) in a [graph](mathematics/graph). It simultaneously searches 
forward from the start node and backward from the goal node, stopping when the two searches meet. This approach 
typically uses [breadth-first search](mathematics/breadth_first_search) from both directions. 
By searching from both ends, the algorithm can significantly reduce the search space and find the path more 
efficiently than searching in only one direction.

nodes.title: breadth-first search
nodes.content:
# breadth-first search


The [breadth-first search](mathematics/breadth_first_search) is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) for traversing or searching 
a [graph](mathematics/graph) structure. It explores all [nodes](mathematics/node) at the current 
depth level before moving to nodes at the next depth level. The algorithm starts at a given node and 
systematically visits all neighboring nodes first, then visits all unvisited neighbors of those neighbors, 
and so on. This level-by-level exploration ensures that the shortest [path](mathematics/path) 
(in terms of number of [edges](mathematics/edge)) is found first in non-[weighted graphs](mathematics/weighted_graph).

nodes.title: depth-first search
nodes.content:
# depth-first search


The [depth-first search](mathematics/depth_first_search) is an [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) for traversing or searching 
a [graph](mathematics/graph) structure. It explores as far as possible along each [path](mathematics/path) 
before backtracking. The algorithm starts at a given [node](mathematics/node) and follows 
[edges](mathematics/edge) to visit a neighbor, then recursively visits that neighbor's unvisited neighbors, 
and so on, until it reaches a [node](mathematics/node) with no unvisited neighbors, at which point it backtracks. 
This approach goes deep into the graph structure before exploring other paths.

nodes.title: bottom_up_approach
nodes.content:
# bottom_up_approach


A [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) design approach that constructs [solutions](mathematics/solution) 
to a [problem](mathematics/problem) by first solving its smaller [subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) 
and then combining those solutions to form a solution to the original problem. The bottom-up approach often avoids 
[recursion](mathematics/recursion) by iteratively building up answers from the [base cases](mathematics/base_case).

nodes.title: top_down_approach
nodes.content:
# top_down_approach


A [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) design approach that breaks a [problem](mathematics/problem) into smaller
[subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) and solves them using [recursion](mathematics/recursion). The top-down
approach typically stores results of subproblems when the problem exhibits 
[overlapping_subproblems](mathematics/overlapping_subproblems), avoiding redundant work and building solutions 
from those stored results.

nodes.title: half_and_half_approach
nodes.content:
# half_and_half_approach


A [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) design approach that solves a [problem](mathematics/problem) by dividing it 
into two equal or nearly equal halves, solving each half independently (often using [recursion](mathematics/recursion)), 
and then combining the [solutions](mathematics/solution) from both halves. This approach is particularly 
effective for problems where the [subproblems](mathematics/subproblem) can be balanced and 
solved in parallel or sequentially with reduced [complexity](mathematics/complexity).

nodes.title: mathematical programming
nodes.content:
# mathematical programming


[mathematical programming](mathematics/mathematical_programming) is a mathematical approach to finding the [optimal solution](mathematics/optimal_solution) 
to a [problem](mathematics/problem) by [optimizing](mathematics/optimization) an [objective function](mathematics/objective_function) subject to [constraints](mathematics/constraint). 
The goal is to maximize or minimize the objective function while ensuring the solution is a [feasible solution](mathematics/feasible_solution).

nodes.title: constraint
nodes.content:
# constraint


[constraint](mathematics/constraint) is a [condition](mathematics/criterion) or restriction that must be satisfied 
by any valid [solution](mathematics/solution) to a [problem](mathematics/problem). Constraints define [bounds](mathematics/bound) 
and limitations within which a solution must operate, determining which solutions are acceptable and which are not.

nodes.title: objective function
nodes.content:
# objective function


[objective function](mathematics/objective_function) is a [function](mathematics/function) that represents the goal or objective 
to be [optimized](mathematics/optimization) in a [problem](mathematics/problem). The objective function is either maximized or minimized 
to find the best solution, and its value determines the quality of any given solution.

nodes.title: feasible solution
nodes.content:
# feasible solution


[feasible solution](mathematics/feasible_solution) is a [solution](mathematics/solution) to a [problem](mathematics/problem) 
that satisfies all the [constraints](mathematics/constraint). A feasible solution may not be optimal, 
but it meets all the requirements and restrictions of the problem.

nodes.title: off-by-one
nodes.content:
# off-by-one


[off-by-one](mathematics/off_by_one) is a common error in [algorithms](mathematics/algorithm) where a [loop](mathematics/loop) iterates 
one time too many or one time too few, or where an [index](mathematics/index) is off by one position. This often occurs when using 
zero-based indexing or when defining loop boundaries incorrectly. Off-by-one errors can lead to incorrect results 
or missing the first or last element of a sequence.

nodes.title: object
nodes.content:
# object


An object is an instance of a [data structure](computer_science/data_structure).

nodes.title: data
nodes.content:
# data


A collection of discrete or continuous values that convey [information](mathematics/information), 
describing the quantity, quality, fact, statistics, other basic units of meaning, or simply sequences of symbols 
that may be further interpreted formally.

nodes.title: data_structure
nodes.content:
# data_structure


A data structure is a way of organizing and storing [data](computer_science/data) so it can be accessed 
and modified efficiently. A data structure contains a value or group of values and the functions or operations 
that can be applied to the data.

nodes.title: data_type
nodes.content:
# data_type


Data type (or simply type) is a grouping of [data](computer_science/data) values, usually specified by a 
[set](mathematics/set) of possible values, a [set](mathematics/set) of allowed 
operations on these values, and/or a representation of these values as machine types.

nodes.title: operation
nodes.content:
# operation


Operation is an action that is carried out to accomplish a given task. In the most simple scenario, it is an 
action performed on at least one [object](computer_science/object).

nodes.title: bit
nodes.content:
# bit


The bit (binary digit) is the smallest unit of data in computing, representing a binary state of either 0 or 1. 
Bits are the fundamental building blocks of [data](computer_science/data) and can convey basic forms of 
[information](mathematics/information) by representing true/false or data/off states.

nodes.title: binary representation
nodes.content:
# binary representation


[binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation) is a way of expressing [information](mathematics/information) using only two symbols, typically 0 and 1. 
In this system, each digit is called a [bit](computer_science/bit), and [sequences](mathematics/sequence) of bits are used to represent [numbers](mathematics/number) 
and other types of information.

nodes.title: binary fractions
nodes.content:
# binary fractions


[binary fractions](computer_science/binary_fractions) are a way to represent fractional [numbers](mathematics/number) 
using [binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation). In binary fractions, 
[bits](computer_science/bit) to the right of a binary point represent negative powers of 2 
(1/2, 1/4, 1/8, etc.), similar to how digits after a decimal point in base-10 represent 
negative powers of 10. For example, the binary fraction 0.101 represents 1/2 + 0/4 + 1/8 = 5/8.

nodes.title: bitwise operation
nodes.content:
# bitwise operation


[bitwise operation](computer_science/bitwise_operation) is an [operation](computer_science/operation) that acts on individual [bits](computer_science/bit) 
within a [binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation). Bitwise operations work directly on the bits of [data](computer_science/data), 
allowing for efficient manipulation and comparison at the lowest level of representation.

nodes.title: arithmetic right shift
nodes.content:
# arithmetic right shift


[arithmetic right shift](computer_science/arithmetic_right_shift) is a [bitwise operation](computer_science/bitwise_operation) 
and a variant of [right shift](computer_science/right_shift) that preserves the sign 
[bit](computer_science/bit) when shifting signed [integers](mathematics/integer). 
Instead of filling the leftmost positions with zeros, it replicates the sign bit, 
maintaining the correct sign for negative numbers in [two's complement](computer_science/twos_complement) 
representation. This [operation](computer_science/operation) effectively performs signed integer 
division by powers of 2.

nodes.title: hardware
nodes.content:
# hardware


[hardware](computer_science/hardware) refers to the physical components of a [computer](computer_science/computer) system. 
These are tangible parts that can be touched and manipulated.

nodes.title: computer
nodes.content:
# computer


[computer](computer_science/computer) is a device that can execute [instructions](mathematics/instruction) 
to process [information](computer_science/data) and perform tasks automatically. A computer can store, retrieve, and manipulate 
data according to instructions.

nodes.title: computer memory
nodes.content:
# computer memory


[computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) is a [hardware](computer_science/hardware) component that stores [data](computer_science/data) for immediate use 
by a [computer](computer_science/computer). It provides storage for [instructions](mathematics/instruction) and data that are actively being processed or accessed, 
enabling the computer to perform [operations](computer_science/operation) efficiently.

nodes.title: concurrency
nodes.content:
# concurrency


[concurrency](computer_science/concurrency) is the ability of a [program](computer_science/program) to execute multiple tasks or [operations](computer_science/operation) 
simultaneously or in overlapping time periods. In concurrent execution, multiple tasks make progress without necessarily 
running at the exact same instant, allowing for more efficient use of system resources and improved responsiveness. 
Concurrency enables programs to handle multiple operations such as user input or 
background processing at the same time.

nodes.title: core
nodes.content:
# core


[core](computer_science/core) is an independent processing unit within a [processor](computer_science/processor) 
that can execute [instructions](mathematics/instruction) and perform [operations](computer_science/operation) 
independently of other cores. Modern processors often contain multiple cores, enabling them to execute multiple 
tasks simultaneously, which is essential for parallel computing.

nodes.title: parallelism
nodes.content:
# parallelism


[parallelism](computer_science/parallelism) is a form of [concurrency](computer_science/concurrency) where multiple [operations](computer_science/operation) 
or tasks are executed simultaneously at the exact same time, typically by utilizing multiple [processors](computer_science/processor) or [cores](computer_science/core). 
Unlike [concurrency](computer_science/concurrency), which is about managing multiple tasks that may overlap in time, 
[parallelism](computer_science/parallelism) specifically requires the physical simultaneous execution of tasks. This approach enables 
[programs](computer_science/program) to achieve significant performance improvements by dividing work across multiple processing units.

nodes.title: processor
nodes.content:
# processor


[processor](computer_science/processor) is a [hardware](computer_science/hardware) component of a [computer](computer_science/computer) 
that executes [instructions](mathematics/instruction) and performs [operations](computer_science/operation) 
on data. It is the central component responsible for carrying out the computational tasks defined by [programs](computer_science/program), 
often referred to as the central processing unit (CPU).

nodes.title: program
nodes.content:
# program


[program](computer_science/program) is a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of [instructions](mathematics/instruction) that a [computer](computer_science/computer) 
can execute to perform a specific task. A program defines the [operations](computer_science/operation) that should be carried out and 
the order in which they should be executed.

nodes.title: random access memory
nodes.content:
# random access memory


[random access memory](computer_science/random_access_memory) is a type of [computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) that allows [data](computer_science/data) to be read or written 
in almost the same amount of time regardless of the physical location of the data within the memory. 
This enables fast access to any memory location, making it suitable for storing data that needs to be 
quickly accessed and modified during [program](computer_science/program) execution.

nodes.title: right shift
nodes.content:
# right shift


[right shift](computer_science/right_shift) is a [bitwise operation](computer_science/bitwise_operation) 
that shifts all [bits](computer_science/bit) in a 
[binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation) to the right by a 
specified number of positions. Right shift by one position is equivalent to 
[integer](mathematics/integer) division by 2.

nodes.title: heap memory
nodes.content:
# heap memory


[heap memory](computer_science/heap_memory) is a region of [computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) used for dynamic [memory allocation](computer_science/memory_allocation) 
during [program](computer_science/program) execution. It allows [data](computer_science/data) to be allocated and deallocated 
at runtime as needed. The heap provides flexible memory management where 
memory blocks can be allocated in any order and freed in any order.

nodes.title: heap overflow
nodes.content:
# heap overflow


[heap overflow](computer_science/heap_overflow) occurs when a [program](computer_science/program) attempts to use more [heap memory](computer_science/heap_memory) 
than is available. This typically happens when too much dynamic [memory allocation](computer_science/memory_allocation) occurs without 
proper deallocation, or when attempting to allocate a very large amount of memory at once. When heap overflow occurs, 
the program may fail to allocate memory and typically terminates with an error.

nodes.title: logical right shift
nodes.content:
# logical right shift


[logical right shift](computer_science/logical_right_shift) is a [bitwise operation](computer_science/bitwise_operation) 
and a variant of [right shift](computer_science/right_shift) that always fills the 
leftmost [bits](computer_science/bit) with zeros, regardless of the sign of the 
[integer](mathematics/integer). This [operation](computer_science/operation) treats the 
[binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation) as an unsigned value, 
making it suitable for unsigned integer division by powers of 2.

nodes.title: stack memory
nodes.content:
# stack memory


[stack memory](computer_science/stack_memory) is a region of [computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) used for static [memory allocation](computer_science/memory_allocation) 
during [program](computer_science/program) execution. It stores [data](computer_science/data) in a [last in first out](mathematics/last_in_first_out) order, 
automatically allocating and deallocating memory as [functions](mathematics/function) are called and return. The stack manages local 
[variables](computer_science/variable) and function call information.

nodes.title: call stack
nodes.content:
# call stack


[call stack](computer_science/call_stack) is a region of [stack memory](computer_science/stack_memory) that tracks active 
[function](mathematics/function) calls during [program](computer_science/program) execution. 
It stores [information](mathematics/information) about each function call, including where to return after 
the function completes. When a function is called, its information is added to the call stack, 
and when it returns, that information is removed.

nodes.title: cache
nodes.content:
# cache


[cache](computer_science/cache) is a high-speed [computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) storage layer that temporarily 
holds frequently accessed or recently used [data](computer_science/data) to reduce access time and improve performance. 
When data is requested, the cache is checked first; if the data is found (a cache hit), it can be retrieved quickly 
without accessing slower storage. If not found (a cache miss), the data must be fetched from the original source 
and may be stored in the cache for future use.

nodes.title: stack overflow
nodes.content:
# stack overflow


[stack overflow](computer_science/stack_overflow) occurs when a [program](computer_science/program) attempts to use more [stack memory](computer_science/stack_memory) 
than is available. This typically happens when the [call stack](computer_science/call_stack) grows too large, often due to 
excessive [function](mathematics/function) [recursion](mathematics/recursion) or allocating too many local [variables](computer_science/variable). When stack overflow occurs, 
the program usually terminates with an error.

nodes.title: memory allocation
nodes.content:
# memory allocation


[memory allocation](computer_science/memory_allocation) is the [operation](computer_science/operation) of assigning a block of [computer memory](computer_science/computer_memory) 
to store [data](computer_science/data) for use by a [program](computer_science/program). It determines where and how much memory 
is reserved for storing [information](mathematics/information) during program execution.

nodes.title: variable
nodes.content:
# variable


[variable](computer_science/variable) is a named storage location identified by a [label](mathematics/label) 
that holds [data](computer_science/data) which can be modified during program execution. 
A variable associates a name with a value that can change over time.

nodes.title: two's complement
nodes.content:
# two's complement


[two's complement](computer_science/twos_complement) is a mathematical operation and 
[binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation) method used to represent 
signed [integers](mathematics/integer) in computing. In this representation, positive 
[numbers](mathematics/number) are represented in standard binary form, 
while negative [numbers](mathematics/number) are represented by inverting all 
[bits](computer_science/bit) of their positive counterpart and adding 1. 
This method allows both positive and negative [integers](mathematics/integer) to be represented and 
enables arithmetic operations to be performed using the same hardware circuitry, making it the most common method for 
representing signed integers.

nodes.title: abstract_data_type
nodes.content:
# abstract_data_type


Abstract data type (ADT) is a mathematical model for [data type](computer_science/data_type), defined by 
its behavior from the point of view of a user of the [data](computer_science/data), specifically in terms 
of possible values, possible [operations](computer_science/operation) on data of this 
[data type](computer_science/data_type), and the behavior of these 
[operations](computer_science/operation).

nodes.title: bit_field
nodes.content:
# bit_field


A bit field is a [data structure](computer_science/data_structure) that consist of one or more adjacent 
[bits](computer_science/bit) which have been allocated for specific purposes, so that any single bit or 
group of bits within the structure can be set or inspected.

nodes.title: collection
nodes.content:
# collection


Collection is an [abstract data type](computer_science/abstract_data_type) that groups some variable 
number of [data structures](computer_science/data_structure) (possibly zero) that have some shared 
significance to the problem being solved and need to be [operated](computer_science/operation) upon 
together in some controlled fashion.

nodes.title: map
nodes.content:
# map


A [data structure](computer_science/data_structure) that maps keys to values. Each key can map to at 
most one value. It models the mathematical function abstraction.

nodes.title: primitive_data_type
nodes.content:
# primitive_data_type


Primitive data types are a [set](mathematics/set) of basic 
[data structures](computer_science/data_structure) from which all other data types are constructed.

nodes.title: associative_array
nodes.content:
# associative_array


An [abstract data type](computer_science/abstract_data_type) that 
[maps](computer_science/map) keys to values. It is a [collection](computer_science/collection) 
of key-value pairs, where each key is unique and is used to access the corresponding value. Associative arrays 
allow for efficient [operations](computer_science/operation): retrieval, insertion, and deletion of 
values based on their keys.

nodes.title: hash_table
nodes.content:
# hash_table


Data structure that implements [associative array](computer_science/associative_array) using a 
[hash function](mathematics/hash_function) to compute an index into an array of buckets or slots, 
from which the desired value can be found. Hash tables are designed to provide fast access to data by using a hash 
function to map keys to indices in an array.

nodes.title: bag
nodes.content:
# bag


A bag is a [collection](computer_science/collection) that allows for the storage of multiple items, 
where the same item can be stored multiple times. It is similar to a 
[multiset](mathematics/multiset), but does not require any specific ordering of the items. Removing 
items is not supported. A bag allows to iterate through the collected items.

nodes.title: set
nodes.content:
# set


A set is an [abstract data type](computer_science/abstract_data_type) that can store unique values, 
without any particular order. It is a computer implementation of the mathematical concept of a 
[finite set](mathematics/finite_set). Unlike most other 
[collection](computer_science/collection) types, rather than retrieving a specific element from a set, 
one typically tests a value for membership in a set.

nodes.title: array
nodes.content:
# array


Array is a [list](computer_science/list) of elements of the same 
[type](computer_science/data_type).

nodes.title: linked_list
nodes.content:
# linked_list


An ordered [collection](computer_science/collection) of elements. Each element is stored in a 
[node](mathematics/node) that contains a reference to the next node in the list. Linked lists can 
be singly linked or doubly linked, depending on whether each node has a reference to the next node only or both the 
next and previous nodes.

nodes.title: list
nodes.content:
# list


An ordered [collection](computer_science/collection). Also known as a sequence. One can add, remove, and 
pop any element from the list. List can store elements of different [types](computer_science/data_type).

nodes.title: priority_queue
nodes.content:
# priority_queue


A priority queue is an [abstract data type](computer_science/abstract_data_type) that operates similarly 
to a regular [queue](computer_science/queue) but with an added feature: each element in the priority 
queue has a 'priority' associated with it. Elements with higher priority are served before elements with lower 
priority. If two elements have the same priority, they are served according to their order in the queue (FIFO - 
First In, First Out).

nodes.title: queue
nodes.content:
# queue


Queue is a [data structure](computer_science/data_structure) providing first-in-first-out (FIFO) 
semantics. Serves as a [collection](computer_science/collection) of elements with two main 
[operations](computer_science/operation):
- Enqueue, which adds an element to the rear of the queue, and
- Dequeue, which removes an element from the front.
Additionally, a peek [operation](computer_science/operation) can, without modifying the queue, return 
the value of the next element to be dequeued without dequeuing it.

nodes.title: stack
nodes.content:
# stack


Stack is a [data structure](computer_science/data_structure) providing last-in-first-out semantics; 
also called a LIFO [queue](computer_science/queue).Serves as a 
[collection](computer_science/collection) of elements with two main 
[operations](computer_science/operation):
- Push, which adds an element to the collection, and
- Pop, which removes the most recently added element.
Additionally, a peek [operation](computer_science/operation) can, without modifying the stack, return 
the value of the last element added. The name stack is an analogy to a [set](mathematics/set) of 
physical items stacked one atop another, such as a stack of plates.

nodes.title: boolean
nodes.content:
# boolean


Boolean (sometimes shortened to Bool) is a [primitive data type](computer_science/primitive_data_type) 
that has one of two possible values usually denoted true and false. Boolean is a 
[bit field](computer_science/bit_field) that stores a single [bit](computer_science/bit) of 
[information](mathematics/information).

nodes.title: integer
nodes.content:
# integer


A [primitive data type](computer_science/primitive_data_type) that represents whole numbers. 
Integers can be positive, negative, or zero.

nodes.title: character_encoding
nodes.content:
# character_encoding


A method of representing characters as numerical values, allowing computers to store and manipulate text. 
Character encoding schemes define the [mapping](computer_science/map) between characters and their 
corresponding numerical values.

nodes.title: ascii
nodes.content:
# ascii


ASCII is a [character encoding](computer_science/character_encoding) standard that uses 7 
[bits](computer_science/bit) to represent 128 characters, including letters, digits, punctuation marks, 
and control characters.

nodes.title: extended_ascii
nodes.content:
# extended_ascii


An extension of the [ASCII](computer_science/ascii) 
[character encoding](computer_science/character_encoding) standard that uses 8 bits to represent 256 
characters, including additional symbols and characters from various languages.

nodes.title: utf
nodes.content:
# utf


UTF (Unicode Transformation Format) is a [character encoding](computer_science/character_encoding) 
standard that represents [Unicode](computer_science/unicode) characters using variable-length sequences 
of bytes.

nodes.title: utf_8
nodes.content:
# utf_8


A [UTF](computer_science/utf) [character encoding](computer_science/character_encoding) 
scheme that uses 1 to 4 bytes to represent [Unicode](computer_science/unicode) characters. It is 
backward compatible with ASCII and can represent any character in the Unicode standard.

nodes.title: unicode
nodes.content:
# unicode


A [character encoding](computer_science/character_encoding) standard that aims to provide a unique 
number for every character, regardless of the system.

nodes.title: regular expression
nodes.content:
# regular expression


A [regular expression](computer_science/regular_expression) is a [sequence](mathematics/sequence) of 
[characters](computer_science/character_encoding) that defines a search pattern for 
[strings](computer_science/string). Regular expressions use special syntax to specify patterns, including 
literal [characters](computer_science/character_encoding), character classes, quantifiers, and anchors. They 
enable powerful text matching, searching, and manipulation operations, allowing users to find, extract, or replace text 
that matches specific patterns. For example, the pattern `[0-9]+` matches one or more digits, and `^[a-z]+$` matches 
[strings](computer_science/string) containing only lowercase letters from start to end. Regular expressions 
can also use groups and [labels](mathematics/label) to capture and reference parts of the matched text.

nodes.title: string
nodes.content:
# string


A sequence of [decoded characters](computer_science/character_encoding), typically used to represent 
text. Strings can be of variable length and can contain letters, numbers, symbols, and whitespace.

nodes.title: substring
nodes.content:
# substring


A contiguous sequence of characters within a [string](computer_science/string). For instance, 
'the best of' is a substring of 'It was the best of times'.

nodes.title: trie
nodes.content:
# trie


A type of [tree](mathematics/tree) data structure that is used to store a dynamic 
[set](mathematics/set) of strings, where the keys are usually strings. Each 
[node](mathematics/node) in the trie represents a single character of a 
[string](computer_science/string), and the path from the root to a node represents a prefix of the 
string. The main advantage of using a trie is that it allows for efficient retrieval of strings with common 
prefixes.

nodes.title: graph_labeling
nodes.content:
# graph_labeling


A [problem](mathematics/problem) of assigning [labels](mathematics/label), traditionally 
represented by [integers](computer_science/integer), to [edges](mathematics/edge) and/or 
[nodes](mathematics/node) of a [graph](mathematics/graph).

nodes.title: graph_coloring
nodes.content:
# graph_coloring


A special case of [graph labeling](computer_science/graph_labeling) where the 
[labels](mathematics/label) are colors.

nodes.title: vertex_coloring
nodes.content:
# vertex_coloring


A specific type of [graph coloring](computer_science/graph_coloring) where the goal is to ensure that 
no two connected [nodes](mathematics/node) share the same color.

nodes.title: hash_collision
nodes.content:
# hash_collision


A situation in which two different inputs produce the same hash value when processed by a 
[hash function](mathematics/hash_function). This can lead to 
[data](computer_science/data) integrity issues and is a key consideration in the design of hash functions and 
[hash tables](computer_science/hash_table).

nodes.title: rolling_hash
nodes.content:
# rolling_hash


A rolling hash is an approach designed to enable efficient execution of the 
[hash function](mathematics/hash_function) when the input is modified incrementally, such as when 
a window of fixed size moves over a [sequence](mathematics/sequence).

nodes.title: rabin_karp_algorithm
nodes.content:
# rabin_karp_algorithm


A string searching [algorithm](mathematics/algorithm) that uses a 
[rolling hash](computer_science/rolling_hash) to find a pattern in a [string](computer_science/string). 
It computes the [hash](mathematics/hash_function) of the pattern and the hash of each 
[substring](computer_science/substring) of the text of the same length as the pattern, and compares them to find matches.

nodes.title: bit manipulation
nodes.content:
# bit manipulation


[bit manipulation](computer_science/bit_manipulation) is a technique that uses [bitwise operations](computer_science/bitwise_operation) to perform direct operations 
on individual [bits](computer_science/bit) or groups of bits in a [binary representation](computer_science/binary_representation). 
It is commonly used in [algorithms](mathematics/algorithm) for tasks like setting, clearing, toggling, 
or checking specific bits, as well as performing efficient computations.
